articles.headline: Trump Has Discussed With Advisers Pardons for His 3 Eldest Children and Giuliani
articles.snippet: Rudolph W. Giuliani, who is promoting baseless claims of widespread election fraud, talked about a pardon with President Trump as recently as last week.
articles.abstract: Rudolph W. Giuliani, who is promoting baseless claims of widespread election fraud, talked about a pardon with President Trump as recently as last week.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump has discussed with advisers whether to grant pre-emptive pardons to his children, to his son-in-law and to his personal lawyer Rudolph W. Giuliani, and talked with Mr. Giuliani about pardoning him as recently as last week, according to two people briefed on the matter.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Salesforce to Acquire Slack for $27.7 Billion
articles.snippet: The move caps an acquisitive streak by Salesforce and ends Slack’s run as an independent publicly traded company.
articles.abstract: The move caps an acquisitive streak by Salesforce and ends Slack’s run as an independent publicly traded company.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Salesforce said on Tuesday that it would buy the workplace software company Slack for $27.7 billion in cash and stock, the latest in a wave of deals as the coronavirus pandemic boosts demand for tools that enable people to work remotely.
articles.byline: By Erin Griffith and Lauren Hirsch

articles.headline: Biden and His Economic Team Urge Quick Action on Stimulus as Risks Mount
articles.snippet: The president-elect introduced key nominees in Delaware, while lawmakers exchanged new proposals with prospects for a deal still dim.
articles.abstract: The president-elect introduced key nominees in Delaware, while lawmakers exchanged new proposals with prospects for a deal still dim.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Tuesday introduced the economic team he will rely on to help rebuild the U.S. economy at a perilous moment, with coronavirus cases soaring, the Federal Reserve chair warning of challenging months ahead and lawmakers in Congress still struggling to reach agreement on a rescue package.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley, Alan Rappeport, Jeanna Smialek, Emily Cochrane and Luke Broadwater

articles.headline: Surging Virus Exposes California’s Weak Spot: A Lack of Hospital Beds and Staff
articles.snippet: Many of the state’s hospitals have maintained lower numbers of beds in part to limit the length of patient stays and lower costs. But that approach is now being tested.
articles.abstract: Many of the state’s hospitals have maintained lower numbers of beds in part to limit the length of patient stays and lower costs. But that approach is now being tested.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For all its size and economic might, California has long had few hospital beds relative to its population, a shortfall that state officials now say may prove catastrophic.
articles.byline: By Thomas Fuller and Manny Fernandez

articles.headline: Barr Acknowledges Justice Dept. Has Found No Widespread Voter Fraud
articles.snippet: The attorney general’s comments were a rebuke of the president’s increasingly spurious claims about election fraud.
articles.abstract: The attorney general’s comments were a rebuke of the president’s increasingly spurious claims about election fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General William P. Barr acknowledged on Tuesday that the Justice Department has uncovered no voting fraud “on a scale that could have effected a different outcome in the election,” a striking repudiation of President Trump’s groundless claims that he was defrauded.
articles.byline: By Katie Benner and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: U.K. Approves Pfizer Coronavirus Vaccine, a First in the West
articles.snippet: The emergency approval, ahead of the United States and the European Union, clears the way for Britain to begin mass inoculations. “Help is on its way,” one official said.
articles.abstract: The emergency approval, ahead of the United States and the European Union, clears the way for Britain to begin mass inoculations. “Help is on its way,” one official said.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain gave emergency authorization on Wednesday to Pfizer’s coronavirus vaccine, leaping ahead of the United States to become the first Western country to allow mass inoculations against a disease that has killed more than 1.4 million people worldwide.

articles.headline: Nobody Is Going to Conventions. Convention Centers Are Growing Anyway.
articles.snippet: The pandemic is intensifying the competition among cities, which are rushing to build bigger, more alluring event spaces.
articles.abstract: The pandemic is intensifying the competition among cities, which are rushing to build bigger, more alluring event spaces.
articles.lead_paragraph: After 20 years of trying, Indianapolis finally landed the American Dental Association convention. Last December, the group agreed to gather there in 2026, promising Indianapolis tens of thousands of visitors and tens of millions of dollars for the local economy.

articles.headline: After Biden Win, Nation’s Republicans Fear the Economy Ahead
articles.snippet: Polling shows that Republicans have turned bearish on the outlook for their family finances since the election, while Democratic optimism is rising.
articles.abstract: Polling shows that Republicans have turned bearish on the outlook for their family finances since the election, while Democratic optimism is rising.
articles.lead_paragraph: Optimism about the economy has taken a nosedive among Republicans. But the economy did not drive the change. The presidential election did.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Ben Casselman

articles.headline: This Japanese Shop Is 1,020 Years Old. It Knows a Bit About Surviving Crises.
articles.snippet: A mochi seller in Kyoto, and many of Japan’s other centuries-old businesses, have endured by putting tradition and stability over profit and growth.
articles.abstract: A mochi seller in Kyoto, and many of Japan’s other centuries-old businesses, have endured by putting tradition and stability over profit and growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: KYOTO, Japan — Naomi Hasegawa’s family sells toasted mochi out of a small, cedar-timbered shop next to a rambling old shrine in Kyoto. The family started the business to provide refreshments to weary travelers coming from across Japan to pray for pandemic relief — in the year 1000.
articles.byline: By Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno

articles.headline: Marc Benioff Sets His Sights on Microsoft
articles.snippet: The Salesforce C.E.O.’s planned acquisition of Slack will have him competing directly with the Goliath that is Microsoft.
articles.abstract: The Salesforce C.E.O.’s planned acquisition of Slack will have him competing directly with the Goliath that is Microsoft.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Five years ago, Marc Benioff negotiated to sell Salesforce, the software company he co-founded in 1999 and has run ever since, to Microsoft. If the deal had gone through, he would have been richly rewarded — but, in the end, just another employee of the tech colossus.
